description: From Middle English feithful, equivalent to faith +â€Ž -ful.

adjectives.description: faithful (comparative faithfuler or more faithful, superlative faithfulest or most faithful)

entries.meaning: Loyal; adhering firmly to person or cause.
examples: My dog is very faithful: he doesn't like to be petted by anybody else.
The application of the old discipline, say the conservatives, would probably produce a smaller but more faithful Church.
I would consider that a very faithful reproduction.

entries.meaning: Engaging in sexual relations only with one's spouse or long-term sexual partner.
examples: They had been faithful to each other all of their married life.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) Injective in specific contexts, e.g. of representations in representation or functors in category theory.
(in the plural) The practicing members of a religion or followers of a cause.
examples: The faithful pray five times a day.

entries.meaning: Someone or something that is faithful or reliable.
